expression

Class Expression

  • java.lang.Object
    • expression.Expression
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable

    public class Expression
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable
    An Expression is a tree which encapsulates arbitrary mathematical functions according to a specific grammar.

    The grammar is as follows:

    Number = At least one digit.
    Variable = A single letter.
    Operator = Either '+', '-', '*', or '/'.

    Expression = Either:
    <Number> Or
    <Variable> Or
    <Expression> <Operator> <Expression>

    This grammar ensures that any function generated will be valid and computable.

    Note: Testing for division by zero should still be done, as the grammar does not account for that.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Constructor Detail

      • Expression

        public Expression(double n)
        Builds an Expression that consists of a single real number. This translates to a function which returns only said number.
        Parameters:
        n - The number the Expression will return.

      • Expression

        public Expression(char v)
        Builds an Expression that consists of a variable. This translates to a function which returns its input.
        Parameters:
        v - The letter to use for the variable.

      • Expression

        public Expression(Expression l,
                  char o,
                  Expression r)
        A binary tree of Expressions. Each side will evaluate to recursively until it hits the terminal nodes of either the Number or Variable Expression type. The halves will be combined according to how the operator dictates.
        Parameters:
        l - The left branch.
        o - The combining operator.
        r - The right branch.

    • Method Detail

      • collapse

        public double collapse(double input)
        Pushes an input number through an Expression, and returns the calculated number. This is like treating the Expression as some f(x), and calling it with an inputed real number. If the function is simply a number, it ignores the input and returns said number. If it's a variable, it returns the input. If it's a complex Expression, the function is solved recursively by first figuring out how to implement the operator with solveExpression(double), then repeating the collapse on each half.
        Parameters:
        input - The real number to pass through the Expression.
        Returns:
        The function's resulting calculated number.
        See Also:
        solveExpression(double)

      • makeFunction

        public BinaryFunction makeFunction()
        Creates a lambda according to the Expression's operator. Useful for turning an Expression's operator into a computable function.
        Returns:
        The lambda based on this Expression's operator.

      • shiftNumber

        public double shiftNumber(double amount)
        Returns a tweaked version of a numerical Expression. Useful for mutations.
        Parameters:
        amount - What to shift the number by.
        Returns:
        The shifted number.

      • print

        public java.lang.String print()
        A wrapper function for print(int), used when you which to print at the head of an Expression tree.
        Returns:
        A stringified Expression.
        See Also:
        print(int)

      • print

        public java.lang.String print(int tabs)
        Recursively pretty-prints this Expression.
        Parameters:
        tabs - How much to indent this section. Deeper sections are indented more.
        Returns:
        A stringified Expression.
        See Also:
        printTabs(int)

        Returns:

        Returns:

      • getLeft

        Returns:

        public Expression getRight()
        Returns:

      • getOperator

        public char getOperator()
        Returns:
